Joe Cannon - Resurrectionists - From Punk Roots to Chamber Americana

The Lorenzo's Music Podcast with Joe Cannon from the band Resurrectionists

Joe Cannon - Resurrectionists - From Punk Roots to Chamber Americana

In this episode of the podcast, I talk with Joe Cannon of the band Resurrectionists. Based in Milwaukee, the band blends genres in their new EP, “Anytime You Make a Place for Them.” The EP includes an Oracle deck that serves as a creative extension of the music. Joe shares how the idea came about and how it reflects the band’s artistic vision.

About Resurrectionists

Resurrectionists, Joe Cannon, Jeff Brueggeman, Josh Barto, and Dr. Science, are a band from Milwaukee, Wisconsin. The band is self-described as “Doom Chamber-Americana,” .

What We Discuss

  • Academia to Music: teaching philosophy to working in bands.
  • Resurrectionists: The band’s formation, evolution, and unique name.
  • Creative Process: Insights into songwriting and recording for their latest EP.
  • Oracle Deck: Artistic pairing of an Oracle deck with their music.
  • Digital Challenges: Navigating music release in the streaming era.

Key Takeaways

  1. Creative Marketing: Oracle deck art and mech.
  2. Collaboration: songwriting and band dynamics.
  3. Music Release Strategy: releasing music in the digital age.
  4. Project Management: managing multiple bands and booking shows.

Connect with Resurrectionists

  • Bandcamp: resurrectionistsmke.bandcamp.com
  • Instagram: @resurrectionists_mke

This episode was recorded on June 29, 2025. Special thanks to Joe Cannon of Resurrectionists for sharing his insights and experiences with me.

Listen to the full episode on your favorite podcast platform or watch the video above.
entry.summary: I talk with Joe Cannon, the guitarist and vocalist from the Milwaukee-based band Resurrectionists. Joe talks about how academia brought him to Milwaukee, where he got involved in the music scene.

entry.title: Lorenzo’s Music Podcast Video Post
entry.content:
Welcome to Lorenzo’s Music! We’re thrilled to finally have our own corner of the internet where we can share our experimental lofi rock journey with you.

Scheduling podcasts

Vlog post

Our Story Begins

What started as late-night jam sessions in a basement studio has evolved into something we never could have imagined. Our sound - a unique blend of atmospheric textures, driving rhythms, and experimental production techniques - has been years in the making.

What to Expect

This website will be your gateway to:

  • New Music: Be the first to hear our latest releases and experimental tracks
  • Behind the Scenes: Get insights into our creative process and recording sessions
  • Live Performances: Stay updated on upcoming shows and watch live session videos
  • Community: Connect with fellow music lovers and share your thoughts on our sound

Our Sound

We describe our music as “experimental lofi rock,” but that barely scratches the surface. We blend:

  • Atmospheric guitar textures that create immersive soundscapes
  • Lofi production techniques that add warmth and character
  • Experimental song structures that defy traditional pop conventions
  • Electronic and organic instrumentation that creates unique sonic landscapes

What’s Next

We’re currently working on our next album, which we’re incredibly excited about. The new material pushes our boundaries even further, exploring new sonic territories while staying true to our core sound.

Stay tuned for more updates, and thank you for joining us on this musical journey!

Keep listening, keep exploring, keep creating.

Follow us on social media for daily updates and behind-the-scenes content.

Basspistol - Music, Promotion and Navigating the Fediverse

The Lorenzo's Music Podcast with Setto the person behind Basspistol

Episode 15: Jon Worthy - From Creative Commons to Full-Time Musician

In this episode, I sit down with Jon Worthy, a Nashville-based musician who has successfully built a full-time career through Creative Commons licensing and community building.

About Jon Worthy

Jon Worthy is a musician, producer, and advocate for open-source music. He’s known for his work in the Creative Commons community and his innovative approach to music distribution and promotion.

What We Discuss

  • Creative Commons Licensing: How Jon uses open licensing to build his audience
  • Community Building: Strategies for connecting with listeners and other musicians
  • Music Promotion: Alternative approaches to traditional music marketing
  • The Fediverse: Exploring decentralized social media for musicians
  • Building a Sustainable Career: Tips for making a living as an independent musician

Key Takeaways

  1. Open licensing can be a powerful tool for building community and getting your music heard
  2. Authentic connections with listeners are more valuable than follower counts
  3. The fediverse offers new opportunities for musicians to connect with audiences
  4. Consistency and quality are key to building a sustainable music career

entry.title: “If I was alone” by Lorenzo’s Music

link.title: “If I was alone” by Lorenzo’s Music

entry.content:
Listen to the song on:

  • Spotify
  • Apple Music
  • YouTube Music
  • Amazon Music

"If I Was Alone" by Lorenzo's Music is a dark, slow-burning track with a heavy lo-fi bassline, marimba, and a chunky electronic beat. A mysterious, warbled guitar adds to the haunting atmosphere. The vocals both shouted and whispered, enhance the song's mixed mood.

Recording Files

You can clone the Ardour DAW recording session files from our GitHub repository and reuse and remix the song.

Clone the song on GitHub here - https://github.com/lorenzosmusic/if-i-was-alone


This song is released under creative commons so you are free to:

Share — use, copy and redistribute the material in any medium or format

Adapt — remix, transform, and build upon the material for any purpose, even commercially.

link.title: Making The Remix: Slippery friction (Tryin’ Mix) with Toucon - Lorenzo’s Music Podcast

entry.content:
Listen to the song "Slippery friction (Tryin' Mix)" on our album Lorenzo's Remixes, Volume 1

Making Beats: The Story Behind "Slippery friction (Tryin' Mix)" for Lorenzo's Remixes Vol. 1

Subscribe to the podcast on: Spotify | Apple Podcasts | YouTube Podcasts | RSS

In this episode, I talk with Toucon (aka Connor Lipke) a producer and musician. He tells me the story behind the beat he created for the remix of our song "Slippery friction" on our EP Lorenzo's Remixes, Volume 1. 

He reveals how he uses tools like FL Studio and Serum VST to structure his beats with a MIDI keyboard and an electronic drum kit.

Toucon explains his process of layering synths and beats, often starting with a simple melody and building complexity from there. He shares insights into his workflow, including how he organizes and sells his beats through platforms like BeatStars.

"Blue Water Friction" by Lorenzo's Music is a throwback to the new wave reggae sound of the 80s, reminiscent of early Joe Jackson or The English Beat. This track, the 5th for a film soundtrack, features echo-y drums, sax riffs, and distinctive guitar sounds.

We recorded this video of the song live from our recording studio using, Ardour, Doidcam, OBS, Kdenlive, and Ubuntu Studio a computer operating system for musicians and artists.

entry.title: Making The Remix: Rainy day friction (Nicholas Burgess Mix) with Nicholas Burgess

link.title: Making The Remix: Rainy day friction (Nicholas Burgess Mix) with Nicholas Burgess

entry.content:
Listen to the song "Rainy day friction (Nicholas Burgess Mix)" on our album Lorenzo's Remixes, Volume 1

The Art of Remixing: Behind the Scenes of "Rainy day friction (Nicholas Burgess Mix)"

Subscribe to the show on: Spotify | Apple Podcasts | YouTube Podcasts | RSS

In this episode, I talk with musician Nicholas Burgess who shares his creative process behind the remix of our song "Rainy Day Friction," a track featured on the recently released EP "Lorenzo's Remixes Volume 1." 

Nicholas describes his approach to remixing as treating the project as if it were his own song. He begins by listening to the original stems, identifying key elements, and building upon them. His goal is to create a remix that not only pays homage to the original but also reflects his own musical style.

Nicholas explains how he selects and manipulates audio, uses MIDI synths, and layers the vocals. We talk about how he chose to focus on the chorus of "Rainy Day Friction," making it the centerpiece of his remix. Nicholas's remixing process also involves experimenting with various instruments and effects, creating a sound that is both contemporary and nostalgic, with influences from new wave and 60s orchestral music.

We also talk about the creative decision to add whispering vocals for a ghostly effect and balancing multiple instrument layers in the mix.

entry.title: Jon Worthy - From Creative Commons to Full-Time Musician - Lorenzo’s Music Podcast

link.title: Jon Worthy - From Creative Commons to Full-Time Musician - Lorenzo’s Music Podcast

entry.content:
Subscribe to the show on: Spotify | Apple Podcasts | YouTube Podcasts | RSS

In this episode of the Lorenzo's Music Podcast, I meet Jon Worthy, a Nashville-based Creative Commons musician. We talk about Jon's beginnings in a college band as a guitarist to becoming a full-time musician. Transitioning from traditional studio recordings to home recordings using tools like Ableton.

Jon also talks about new opportunities he's received over the years including sync licensing for TV shows like "American Ninja Warrior" and "Selling Sunset."

We also talk about releasing his music under Creative Commons license allowing his music to reach wider audiences and be featured in various multimedia projects, from short films to travel vlogs. 

The episode also touches on the challenges of touring, booking shows, his experiences organizing them, and the eventual decision to focus more on music production and less on constant touring. 

Jon recently released a new album, "Barely Here," which he successfully funded through a crowdfunding campaign on Indiegogo. The album is available on vinyl, a medium Jon has long admired for its tangible, artistic appeal. 

Tune in to hear more about Jon Worthy's journey, and his creative process.

Jon Worthy on YouTube - https://www.youtube.com/@jonworthy
